People in that area are going to get slugged when they are driving to Melbourne by having to pay a toll on the Tullamarine Tollway and then having a substantial GST imposed on them.

speech.para: Honourable member interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âThat is right. If you are a high roller and you derive your income from gaming, you will get significant GST tax benefits. Where is the fairness in that?

speech.para: Government members interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âIt is not absolute nonsense.
âOrder! The member for Bendigo will address his remarks through the chair.

âThe City Link tolls on the Tullamarine Tollway will cost motorists about $150,000 a day. This calculation is based on figures of the projected use of the Tullamarine Tollway as given in City Link's prospectus. This projects a weekday use on the Tullamarine Tollway of 104,000 cars, 21,000 light commercial vehicles and 7,000 heavy commercial vehicles. When City Link tolls are in full force, the toll for cars will be $2.02 for the return trip, light commercial vehicles will pay $2.32 and heavy commercial vehicles will pay $3.82âthis, I might add, on a road they already own.

speech.para: Over one year, the total payout of tolls on the Tullamarine Tollway will be about $50 million. The figures for weekend use of the Tullamarine Tollway have not been given, but I calculate that the total City Link toll grab over one year will add up to in excess of $50 million. The GST tax grab will add another $15,000 to the amount paid out per day on the Tullamarine Tollway and $5 million for a year. This is a huge financial drain on motorists from central Victoria and others using the Tullamarine Freeway. The GST raises the cost of a day pass from $7 to $7.70 and a $50 electronic tag to $5.50.

Our region is being especially victimised because we are being funnelled into the western link toll complex which opens in Juneânearly three months ahead of the southern link. So Bendigo region motorists and others using the Tullamarine and the western link are being bled with City Link tolls for nearly three months ahead of other regions. This situation adds insult to injury. Tullamarine is the only country access into the city where City Link tolls are being imposed, and so motorists from central Victoria are the only ones being taxed to drive into their own city. If you live in Geelong, when you drive to Melbourne you do not pay a toll; if you live in Shepparton, when you drive to Melbourne you do not pay a toll; but, if you live in Bendigo or northern Victoria, you get slugged.

Transurban, the company which will operates the tolls can increase these tolls every three months for the next 34 years, under the agreement with the Melbourne City Link Authority. So central Victorians who travel on the Calder Highway may have an ever increasing penalty plus a GST simply by living in central Victoria. This shows how unfair this goods and service tax isâon the one hand, if you live in central Victoria you get slugged for visiting your capital city but, if you live elsewhere in Victoria, you get there free of charge. People in central Victoria get slugged for using a road that most people have already paid for. We have seen for so long government ministers singing the praises of the GST, how it is going to cure just about every aspect of Australian life ranging from our overseas debt to even the common cold. This a prime example of just how unfair this tax is and how it penalises country people.

talk.start.para: âIn the House yesterday the member for Reid, in his speech on the appropriation bill, questioned the validity and basis of a number of key aspects of the Defence Reform Program and the measures included in the 1999-2000 budget. His comments, which I read today, lack either a factual or an analytical basis. It is a problem when we see a member in the House making comments that are basically wrong. I would like to take his comments point by point.

speech.para: The first issue is the reduction in the ADF from 58,000 to 50,000 under the defence reforms. The concern with the overall size of the Defence Force by the member for Reid completely misses the point. What is critical for the government and what is critical for the ADF is what proportion of that force is available for combat and combat support tasks. The defence reform process will result in a real increase in these numbersâ32,500 compared with 25,000 under Labor. The government is moving the people in the ADF to the sharp end. I certainly know that with Australia's largest defence base in my electorate. We can see the benefits of that happening.

I draw the House's attention to the 2,900 reduction in Defence Force numbers set out in the budget documents which relate to support and administrative functions. Those support and administrative functions are still there but of course they are being done much more economically by civilians or contractors. That is allowing members of the ADF to get on with what members of the ADF should be doingâbeing in combat ready or combat support roles.

The second issue was that of the alleged lack of funding for budget initiatives. I respond to the member for Reid by simply saying that the enhancement of Jindalee and the Collins class submarine, which he referred to, will be funded from within the over $2.7 billion which is provided in the defence budget for major capital projects. The honourable member may be unaware that defence has a global budget which provides the necessary flexibility to manage and program such costs. The increase in preparedness levelsâa major initiative which has enjoyed bipartisan supportâagain will be met from the global defence budget, making direct use of the additional resources being made available under the so-called underperforming Defence Reform Program.

I would also like to say that the development of a competitive remuneration structure is an example of welcome innovation in industrial relations. Pay scales will be adjusted in the ADF to much better match a position's salary to its work valueâand, after all, that is what is happening in the wider world. The cost of transition to the new structure including non-reduction provisionsâ$13 million in this year's budgetâis being funded from the overall Defence budget. The third issue is that Defence personnel will receive only a 1.5 per cent pay increase. The ADF is committed to ensuring that members of the Defence Force and the Department of Defence receive a competitive remuneration. The figures referred to by the honourable member for Reid relate only to the expected supplementation for economic factors. The balance of the increase will be found from additional productive gains across the defence forces. This is consistent with the approach that has been adopted across the government.

The fourth issue, a very important one, is that the defence review process savings are not being achieved. I would say to the member for Reid that the defence reform program is well on track to achieve its targeted savings. By the end of 1998-99 the reforms will have achieved $280 million in ongoing savings and this is $30 million already ahead of plan; it is reality, not supposition. As has been made clear in the budget papers, these realised savings will increase to over $450 million in the coming year and to over $860 million by the end of the forward estimates period. The ADF reform program is on track and there is no doubt that the ADF is moving to the sharp end and that in my electorate it is doing wonderfully well for the defence of Australia.

talk.start.para: âTomorrow is the 10th anniversary of the cruel repression of democrats in Tiananmen Square. Although Australians favour maintaining good relations with the PRC and I, as most parliamentarians do, support China joining the World Trade Organisation, we must never put aside our country's support for human rights. Even the size of the PRC or the size of its economic market should not deter Australia from speak ing out when we see injustices. When Australia has been involved in an apparent breach of human rights, it behoves us to indulge in some constructive self-criticism. Any country's reputation is sullied, its name diminished and its ability to protect its citizens weakened when its name is used as a guarantee and that guarantee is then dishonoured.

speech.para: In every Australian loungeroom recently we saw on TV that pathetic video of a Chinese woman deported from Port Hedland back to China. She claimed that, despite the Australian government's assurance of protection for her unborn second child and her own physical safety, she was forcibly aborted on returning to China at Behei City Hospital. Senator Quirke and Senator Harradine have raised other aspects of this affair in the Senate. The basis of my concern is what has happenedâor perhaps more accurately what has not happenedâsince the inquiry was announced by the minister.

Like the shadow minister for immigration and the shadow minister for foreign affairs, the opposition joins the government and the minister in opposing queue-jumping, people traffickers and the modern day slave traders who think Australia is an easy target and a soft touch. I know the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs and, although I do not agree with all of his policies, I know him to be diligent and a person who seeks to apply non-discriminatory criteria to our immigration policy, although he does not always do this to my or the opposition's taste. What I fear is that nothing effective has been done, since the woman's appearance on national television, to give effect to her understanding of assurances of her safety.

I have tabled some detailed questions to the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs about their inaction or action. I have alerted the minister's office to these questions. Understandably, he may not be able to answer them all at this stage. Some of the questions include the following. Is the minister aware of the woman's current whereabouts? Is the minister aware of her condition? Has the woman had any contact with officers of his department since her deportation? What contact has the minister or his department had with relevant officials of the PRC concerning this matter, both before and since her deportation? What measures has his department taken, since this woman's appearance on national television, to fulfil this alleged promise by the Australian government to protect and preserve her physical safety? Was the woman sedated on or about the time of her deportation? If so, by whom and what medication was administered and how much? If so, did the officers of the department or anyone else forcibly restrain her when they administered the sedation? Was there a medical team on board the aircraft when she was returned?

Minister, the essence of the problem is what you or your office has done to effectively preserve the wellbeing of Mrs Zhu Quing Ping. I ask this not as some soft-headed immigration advocate but as an Australian parliamentarian who fears that the obfuscations of the Sir Humphreys and other mandarins will bamboozle the Australian government and public. We apparently gave her a guarantee. We are a great and powerful country and I ask that we put into effect our apparent promise to her. Every Australian has seen how the understanding about this woman's second child has apparently been dishonoured by her forced, ugly and barbaric deportation from Australia. The Australian government's inquiry will perhaps tell us the reasons for this blight on Australia's human rights reputation.

I feel our country, our reputation and our name also stand or fall, Minister, on what happens since you announced the inquiry. If and when Australia moves heaven and earth to safeguard this person's wellbeingâand I note in the meantime that her husband has been arrestedâI hope we will do it not simply because of some forthcoming embarrassment on 60 Minutes or in the Bulletin this week, but because it is the right thing to do. It is nothing short of preserving Australia's reputation and credibility. Yes, Mrs Zhu is a foreigner and, yes, few other countries would go to the trouble suggested here, but we must judge ourselves by our own human rights criteria.

talk.start.para: âIn 1980 the Australian government passed the Whale Protection Act, which banned all whaling in Australian waters. This legislation marked the recognition of the international responsibility needed to create a total ban on all whaling. However, some 19 years laterâand 53 years after the International Convention for the Regulation of Whaling in 1946âwe are still fighting to gain that recognition amongst some nations around the world. Recently I was horrified to read in the Australian an article by a person called Sue Arnold from Australians For Animals Incorporated about a number of issues to do with whaling in the United States. Apparently, in the United States judicial system an Australian group, Australians for Animals, is fighting the United States government to stop the Makah tribe from whaling under the guise of indigenous rights.

speech.para: The Makah tribe are relying on their rights under an 1855 treaty to allow them to undertake whaling activity. Australians for Animals allege that the Endangered Species Act, the Whaling Convention Act, the National Environmental Policy Act and the Marine Mammal Protection and National Marine Sanctuary Act have all been breached by the Clinton administration in allowing the Makah tribe to begin whaling. This case is currently on appeal before the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeal. In spite of pending legal proceedings, the Makah announced their rights and began their whaling activities. This tribe have not partaken in whaling for more than 70 years and cite the reason of cultural restoration to justify their sudden interest in participating in this activity.

Recent reports are that last week in National Marine Sanctuary waters off the coast of the United States the Makah harpooned to death a baby female grey whale that had approached their boat having grown to trust human beings after years of protection from slaughter. How brave of the Makah tribe. The United States Coast Guard plays havoc with protesters' attempts to patrol the barbaric whaling practices, frequently seizing and confiscating protest boats. One week before the killing just mentioned the Coast Guard stormed a protest boat armed with machine guns. They seized the boat and imprisoned the unarmed crew.

Over the next four years, the Makah have claimed the right to kill a further 33 whales. They have denied claims that they plan to sell the meat commercially. However, reports are to the contrary. Already attempts have been made by the Makah to sell whale meat as whale hamburgers to local restaurants. Furthermore, the National Marine and Fisheries Service is `unable to guarantee the Makah will not sell the whale meat commercially'.

Should the appeal in the lawsuit between Australians for Animals and the United States government be unsuccessful, the door is wide open for indigenous claims for whaling rights around the world. Of real concern is the potential for claims from the coasts of Japan and Norway, two well-known whaling countries who desire to whale further. The United States has ignored and defied the International Whaling Commission definition of aboriginal subsistence whaling. Consequently, the potential global ramifications for allowing indigenous rights to override significant environmental laws are obvious to us all and tremendous.

Australia's ultimate goal of a global sanctuary for whales suffers immensely with every incidence of whaling that occurs. The Clinton administration's massive financial and logistical support of the Makah tribe has resulted in a giant step backwards for pro-whale lobby groups and the status of international agreements. The United States were the most powerful pro-whale ally in the world. By endorsing this activity, the US is heading towards the killer nation status of Japan and Norway.

talk.start.para: âShame on them!

âYes, shame on them! 1998 was the 50th anniversary of the International Whaling Commission. Today, 51 years after it was officially recognised that a ban on whaling was an issue of significant international importance, we have just seen another incidence of it. The Australian government must continue to hold strong to our fervent stand against whaling. We have come a long way in the past 50 years. Recent evidence suggests that we have a long way to go.

speech.para: The United States government has not only failed to adhere to much needed international agreements and conventions but also supported claims by indigenous people which are in direct contradiction to their own critical environmental legislation. The United States government sends a very powerful message to the rest of the world in allowing whaling to occur within their waters under any guise. Environmental protection is a concern which needs a continuing fight to ensure that we do not abrogate our responsibilities. Australia leads the world in much of our environmental legislation and for that we can be proud. There is still, however, a long journey ahead of us.

talk.start.para: âThis evening I want to talk about this government, Centrelink and some of the truly confusing, unfair and discriminatory aspects of the decisions of this government within the Centrelink area. I conducted a hotline phone-in on Centrelink some weeks ago in my electorate office following an overwhelming number of calls and contacts to my office by members of the public concerned about decisions, level of service, waiting time for appointments and so on. The Minister for Community Services and the head of Centrelink resorted to writing letters to the editor of the Canberra Times in an attempt not only to blame the victim but also to insinuate that I was basically making all this up. I sent all the details of the calls we received for that isolated period of the phone-in to the ministerâI did not send them to the mediaâin an attempt to convince him of the genuineness of the process and of the honesty of the people calling in.

speech.para: Then this week we had another extraordinary performance by a ministerâthis time the Minister for Family and Community Services, Senator Newmanâbasically accusing the ABC of being prepared to be manipulated by stooge callers set up by the ALP and others. This was the morning after a radio phone-in conducted by the local ABC radio station here in Canberra seeking the views of listeners on the effects of the new Liberal-Democrat GST package. Both these instances distressed me, particularly for this reason: it is no good when a government makes decisions on policies that affect people so directly that the only defence or manner in which they believe they can handle this situation is to blame the victim and to accuse people of lying or misleading the public in transmitting those actions.

I want to give a couple of examples of two particular problems that came to the attention of my office recently. These are the sorts of situations the staff of Centrelink are attempting to deal with. The first one is the case of a young 20-year-old woman who was working full time for just on 12 months and living independently from her family when she fell ill. Unfortunately, and most unusual at 20, she had a stroke. She obviously needed time off work. She applied for sickness allowance to tide her over that period but was told she did not qualify because she was 20 and not 21. If she had been unemployed or a student in receipt of youth allowance, I understand those payments would have continued. But because she had a jobânot a high paying job, I might addâno assistance was available. To the credit of both her employer and her family, appropriate support was offered where possible. I particularly commend her employers because they were very sensitive and compassionate. This young woman, who was a very high achiever at school, is now working out what she might do in her future career. In the meantime she is working in this job. Thankfully, I can report to the House that her health is improving.

Rent assistance is another example. As I understand it, rent assistance is payable if you are a full-time student on youth allowance and aged under 25, but if you happen to be a full-time student aged 25 receiving Austudy payments no rent assistance is available. The constituent I am referring to was a young woman who left school, found your average sort of job, was doing the right thing in trying to decide where to go for her future and, at the age of 25, decided she would attempt to get a degree in veterinary science. This meant, in the ACT, that she had to go to Sydney and, of course, rental levels are such that it became an enormous financial burden for her and her familyâall because she wanted to better herself and gain a professional career, and the decisions of this government precluded her from any rental assistance. If, however, she had done this at an earlier age, say 23 or even 24, she would have gained rent assistance.

It is the arbitrary way of applying barriers based on age, not true circumstances, that makes this all very unfair. These are only two examples but, given the time, I could trot outâand I know my colleagues could alsoâmany more examples. But what do these two ministers do when people have the temerity to ring their local member or call their local radio station? They accuse us all of making it up. I can assure you, Mr Speaker, I have not made these stories up and neither have my constituents. I know we must have been having some effect on these so-called non-existent appointment waiting times and so on when staff in the local Centrelink office are told to keep waiting times for appointments as tight as possible to avoid situations where Annette Ellis does not have the ammunition to attack the government again. I will continue to do so where necessary. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âA little over a year ago, I stood in this place to pay tribute to the extraordinary men and women who selflessly give of themselves to care for a family member or a loved one with a disability. For my interest in their plight, I earned the unenviable task of convening the Unmet Needs Reference Group formed to provide advice to the federal minister. The Unmet Needs Reference Group was activated by the former Minister for Family Services, Warwick Smith, and carried forward by the Minister for Family and Community Services, Senator Jocelyn Newman. The group comprised Michael Sumner, ACROD President; Kevin Stone, President of NCID; Senator John Tierney; and me as convenor.

speech.para: Tonight I rise to reflect on the insights I gained as convenor of the reference group and put on the record some personal observations contained in my recent keynote address to the Council of Intellectual Disability Agencies 1999 conference. In 1996, the Australian Health and Welfare Institute estimated that the annual cost of meeting the unmet need for accommodation and support services and respite care and day programs is around $294 million. It is a known, huge and compelling public policy challenge for our nation, more than a generation in the making. A partnershipâbuilt on a greater funding commitment from governments, a more constructive approach from peak organisations to finding a way forward and a renovation of disability policyâis required to tackle the unmet need for people with a disability and their carers.

The willingness of the federal government to contribute more resources to help the states and territories meet their obligations under the Commonwealth-state disability agreement is welcome leadership that must activate real commitments from other parties. The Commonwealth's additional funding must leverage additional resources from the states and territories so that they demonstrate a genuine commitment to meeting their own obligations under the CSDA. The key and most pressing areas of unmet need did not appear overnight. They happened, principally in services of state and territory jurisdiction, over decades and within program service areas sought and signed up for by the states and territories under the CSDAs. Real partnerships involve real commitments. On the strength of the budget information released to date from states and territories, I am not sure whether we have seen a real commitment from the state and territory governments.

It is for the states and territories to resolve their priorities and not for the Commonwealth to reward underperformance in service areas which have been the long-term responsibility of the states. Given the anticipated differing responses of the states and territories, I expect that a series of bilateral agreements will need to be negotiated with the Commonwealth. These agreements should provide the flexibility to reflect the extent of the challenge in each jurisdiction, current effort and efficiency performances, the priority assigned to the task by the state and territory governments, and the forward budgeting and policy considerations of each government.

Beyond expanded and targeted service commitments negotiated between the partners, all agreements should include core elements such as committing governments to a joint approach to future planning of services; a review of current service delivery models; performance indicators, benchmarking and reporting; quality standards and information sharing; and the cooperative trialling of new service models. The reference group called for decisive action to implement a response plan or action agenda to address the significant extent of unmet needs of people with disabilities and their families. An action agenda for unmet needs should embrace the concept of planned and strategic intervention, where services are available when and where they are needed rather than in response to a crisis emerging.

The reference group suggested priorities for action commencing with unmet accommodation needs and support services for people currently looked after by an ageing carer and retirement style accommodation for ageing people with disabilities. I will not go through the other priority areas, given the time available. The disability sector peak organisations need to play a more constructive role in shaping agreed pathways to addressing unmet needs, show a greater willingness to embrace innovation and undertake a re-examination of disability policies which stand in the way of cost-effective service models being implemented.

As a personal commitment, I have undertaken to pursue the formation of an All-Party Disability Group as a way of building a parliamentary constituency for the necessary political will required to tackle the significant challenges of unmet needs. I invite colleagues in this place and the Senate to join in this non-partisan endeavour to bring about meaningful progress in the challenge of meeting the unmet need for disability services for people with disabilities and the national heroes who are their carers.

talk.start.para: âI wish to add to my adjournment speech made earlier in the Main Committee with respect to Chris Corrigan, the DPP and allegations of perjury. I neglected to mention that, after the DPP decided to take no action with respect to the matters referred to him and, indeed, to take no further action to seek further investigation of these matters by referring them to the Australian Federal Police, the matter has subsequently been referred to the Australian Federal Police by Mr John Coombs. He has done what the DPP should have done.

speech.para: The DPP's pre-emptory decision now creates a real problem. Having previously decided not only not to prosecute but also not to take any further steps to have the matter investigated, it is going to be rather difficult for the DPP to respond to any recommendation by the AFP that there should be action taken. I reiterate my call for the government to explain how this extraordinary behaviour by the DPP occurred and to guarantee that no political interference has occurred because of the involvement of Mr Corrigan and the political nature of this issue.

talk.start.para: âIt being 6 p.m., the debate is interrupted.

debate.para: (1) recognises the vital and growing role electronic information transmission plays in education, research and business activity throughout Australia;

(2) further recognises that the availability of adequate capacity, high quality and appropriately priced bandwidthâfor the electronic transmission of informationâis an important strategic issue for the development of the information economy in Australia;
(3) notes that regional areas throughout Australia have a poorer electronic information infrastructure than metropolitan areas, and the gap is widening; and
(4) acknowledges the urgent need to provide affordable broadband electronic communica tions to Australia's regional centres and, in particular, to our regional universities.
(1) that the national taxation debate is not longer about `tax reform' but merely about `tax change'âand not change for the better;

(2) the Coalition-Democrat tax deal will, in the official estimate of the Treasurer, cost at the very least $20 billion over the first three years of the next centuryâin terms of the erosion of the Commonwealth budget surplus caused by
the ANTS package, as modified by the Australian Democrats;

(3) the GST fiasco on food alone will create enormous compliance burdens for 370 000 small businesses, in the estimate of the Tax Commissioner, and will, in the words of the Premier of Victoria, be `just diabolical' for businesses such as milkbars and small family-run supermarkets; and

(4) as a result of the GST food fiasco, the States will be required to keep indefinitely a range of state taxes and duties amounting to $2.5 billion which the Government promised prior to the last election would be abolished.

business.start.para: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER(Mr Jenkins) took the chair at 9.40 a.m.

talk.start.para: âHaving been a member of parliament for eight months now, one of the most disturbing trends I have noticed is the increase in the number of my constituents coming to see me at the electorate office to talk about how they can no longer cope financially. These are not people who are in need of a financial counsellor; they are people who are good managers of their household budgets and who make the most of their limited financial resources. What they need are changes in government policies which will restore their standard of living that is gradually being eaten away. They are pensioners, widows, self-funded retirees, young families, retrenched workers in their late 40s and 50s, people with small businesses trying to make a go of it on little more than the dole, people with chronic illnesses, and non-custodial parents whose financial circumstances have diminished or who have started a second relationship.

speech.para: This is probably not an exhaustive list of the groups in our community who are in real financial trouble, but look at the problems people in these groups face. Pensioners' living standards have been gradually eroded because the CPI does not reflect the basket of goods that they buy. Inflation has been low, but that is in large part because mortgage interest rates have been historically low. Relatively few pensioners have mortgages. The essential things that they buy have been going up by more than inflation. If they are in public housing, the state government takes 25 per cent of any pension increase they happen to receive. Similar financial pressures apply to widows.

Self-funded retirees are feeling the pinch, ironically because of low interest rates; their assets are no longer generating the kind of income they generated a few years ago, and these people are being forced onto part-pensions. Many are concerned that they are gradually being forced to run down their assets to make ends meet. Young families on low incomes always have a hard battle, and the Howard government has made that battle that much harder by increasing the cost to those families of child care, often to the point where it removes the option for young mothers to do at least some part-time work.

Retrenched workers over 55 have been specifically targeted by this government. They have been prematurely deemed to have retired if they cannot find a job so that the government can count the superannuation of these retrenched workers in the assets test for social security benefits. The period after the kids leave home and prior to retirement is when most Australians have done that extra bit of saving to build up a nest egg for their retirement. Without a job they cannot do that. But this government is compounding the problem by forcing them to run down their superannuation assets, so they will have a reduced standard of living both now and after they reach retiring age.

Administratively the social security system is not user friendly to those many Australians who are trying to stand on their own financial feet by running a small business which, when it is getting started, means long periods of fluctuating income, often at levels which are just above or just below what they would be getting on the dole. With the Howard government's changes to the pharmaceutical schedule and benefits, chronic illness also means real financial hardship. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âOne of the means by which I keep across the range of views and concerns in my electorate of Moreton is the Moreton Youth Advisory Group. I would encourage other members in this place to use a similar approach. By deliberately seeking representatives from each of the high schools in my electorate, I have been able to access the views of young citizens, those who will be the citizens running this country tomorrow, in order to try to keep me across their views and concerns and their aspirations for the nation that they will inherit. I think it is an important process because, after all, everything we do in this place these days could be easily undone by those who follow us.

speech.para: The students from Clairvaux MacKillop College; Sunnybank State High School; MacGregor High School, my old high school; Redeemer College; and also the Southside Education Centreâwhich is an independent learning facility giving a second chance to students who perhaps have fallen foul of the law or who, because of domestic circumstances, find themselves in difficult situationsâhave all contributed representatives to the most recent meeting of the Moreton Youth Advisory Group. Students from Yeronga and Nyanda are also regular attendees at this forum.

At the most recent meeting a number of, I think, very interesting observations were made in particular about how we treat Aboriginal Australians in this country and about the general understanding that most people in this nation have towards Australia's first residents. There is a need, I was told by Kylie from Sunnybank, to respect, acknowledge and have an awareness of various cultural days within our communities. Malcolm from Clairvaux MacKillop said that he felt that, in multicultural Australia and the rush towards understanding cultures from other nations, perhaps Aboriginals have been left behind. Kylie from Sunnybank also said that just giving money to Aboriginal causes is not really the answer.

Jessica from MacGregor made the observation that, whilst many people say an apology for the stolen generations is a good thing to do, we do not really fully understand exactly what it is we are apologising for. I think Penny from Redeemer made the comment that there needs to be more education about Aboriginal Australians, their culture and their history in this nation and an understanding of where they are these days. A couple of young ladies, who themselves are of Aboriginal heritage, from the Southside Education Centre made the point that, `You have to live on our side of the fence to understand that often police judge you because of the colour of your skin.'

I think all of these are very real and telling observations from young Australians. I guess what I get out of them is the need to encourage good and proper education that is well rounded and a good understanding of Aboriginal culture to help all Australians live together in harmony.

talk.start.para: âI rise today to pay tribute to the valuable work performed in my electorate by St Francis Xavier Cabrini Hospital and in particular the hospital's extensive outreach program. In 1999 Cabrini funded approximately $1 million worth of community service projects. Such work includes the Sacred Heart Mission, where Cabrini provides 1,000 meals per week for homeless people; the Cabrini Lighthouse for youth at high risk; the Cabrini CentreCare Counselling Service; projects in Swaziland and the Philippines; and the Santa Teresa Aboriginal Mission in the Northern Territory. Cabrini also offers employment for socially disadvantaged youth.

speech.para: Cabrini supports the Open Family/Cabrini bus. This bus goes to inner city and suburban areas known to be frequented by street people, offering them food, friendship and medical and material aid. It is also an important counselling or resource referral point for many people.

I have spoken in the House previously of the activities of the Sacred Heart Mission, located in Grey Street, St Kilda, which is around the corner from my office. Cabrini, through the mission, provides over 60,000 meals per annum for the clients of the mission, and Cabrini food service staff provide the labour to produce the meals. Support is also given for all their fundraising functions. Cabrini staff volunteer their help on Christmas Day to serve the clients of the Sacred Heart Mission, and Cabrini also funds the laundry and general maintenance of the Sacred Heart Mission.

Cabrini's Lighthouse Project provides long-term family rehabilitation for young people who are homeless, who have drug problems or who have been abused. Lighthouse is running at full capacity. Volunteers from the hospital are providing friendship, cooking meals and offering general support to the residents. Two residents from the house are currently employed at the hospital. I take this opportunity to record my admiration for the work of Sue Barton, who provides a family atmosphere at the mother house, and Warren Holland, who runs the Albert Park house in my electorate.

Michael, a young man who has benefited from the deep care shown by Lighthouse, described his journey back from heroin addiction. `Heroin,' he told me, `provided a world to which those who already had problems could retreat.' Michael gave me the most profound insight I have had to date into the reasons for addiction. `Heroin often gave addicted young people some structure,' he said. `Heroin', he said, `was like an evil parent, but a parent nonetheless'.

Cabrini Hospital is a not-for-profit hospital; it is not in receipt of government funding. It provides core medical services, as I can testify. The care that the nursing staff gave me and my brother during the two weeks prior to my father's death in the oncology department was greatly comforting. The hospital's profits are spent on improving the lot of those in need in my electorate and in the wider communityâindeed, as far as away as Swaziland.

Cabrini Outreach Program and the Lighthouse Project are deserving of far more recognition than I am capable of giving them. They are an excellent example of the way humanity and human decency can survive and thrive in a free market economy. Their activities distil the key difference in the world view of Labor from the current government's. Whilst we are for a market economy, we are not for a market society.

talk.start.para: âMr Deputy Speaker, I quote from an article by Dick Tombs entitled `The magic of angling becomes therapy', in the Sunday Mail `Sport Extra' of 25 May:

speech.para: One very special moment about 18 months ago led Graham Plummer to form the Sunshine Coast's own recreational angling support group for the disabled.
"I was in Kmart Maroochydore when I walked into the fishing section and saw a young fellow, probably 8 or 10 years old, sitting in a wheelchair holding a rod.
The look on his face was pure joy and there wasn't any water or fish in sight. I said to my wife, Yvonne, `I'd love to take that kid fishing, see the look on his face.'"
That was when the seed was sown which has now germinated into an incorporated association dealing with leisure and fishing outings for the disabled.

I want to use this forum to pay tribute to Graham Plummer and to the Sport and Leisure for the Handicapped Association on the Sunshine Coast, which trades as the Recreational Association for the Disabled. It is a non-profit organisation dedicated to improving recreational activities for physically handicapped children. The president, Mr Plummer, is a master fisherman and an outstanding individual. He is a very fine citizen in our Sunshine Coast community. He conducts these recreational boat trips for handicapped children, giving the kids the opportunity to do some fishingâan opportunity which would be denied them if it was not for this wonderful association.

Not only does this service provide a memorable and incredibly fulfilling experience for some special kids; it also provides valuable respite care for the families of these incredible children when carers take the children out on the water for a trip. Mr Plummer's service helps lighten the load of families of children with disabilities by offering a service which is both recreational and educational for their children. Without this service, many of these families would not otherwise have these opportunities available to them. I wish to in this place pay tribute to Mr Graham Plummer and to his colleagues who are providing this service to a large extent at their own personal expense. All carers are involved in this project in a totally honorary capacity. Various local businesses have assisted the association with in-kind contributions and, in an attempt to promote this venture, I participated in an interview on ABC Radio on the Sunshine Coast this week. This is a wonderful project. I commend it and I would like to pay tribute to Mr Graham Plummer and those who assist him.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Public Transport

talk.start.para: âWhile I would like to leave it to others to work out whether the Australian Democrats and the government have taxed chickens, whole or in parts, I would like to comment on what we know for certain the Democrats have taxed. In particular, I would like to focus on the Democrats and their broken promise of no GST on public transport. This is of particular importance to the people of my electorate in Oxley and to anybody else living in regional Australia. A GST on public transport highlights the regressive nature of this tax. It is regressive because it taxes the poor harder than it taxes the rich. Every day thousands of people catch the train from Ipswich in the electorate of Oxley to commute to work in Brisbane. Of course, the cost of a ticket depends on the length of the journey, and the electorate of Oxley is quite some distance from the centre of Brisbane, therefore people who live in the electorate of Oxley, who already pay more for their train tickets than inner city folk, will now pay even more again under the GST.

speech.para: Like other parts of Australia, those living in the regions and outer suburbs are the ones generally doing it a little tougher than their city cousins. Now we are asked to contribute an unfair share of GST just because we live outside the big cities, whether by choice or for economic or social reasons. As an example, a worker travelling from Ipswich train station to Brisbane is faced with a 10 per cent GST on their travel every day. At current ticket prices, they will be over $7 a fortnight worse off. On the other hand, a lawyer from Toowong will pay GST on the $3 cost of their journey and pay only half the tax of people from the outer suburbs. This is Robin Hood in reverse: the government is taking from the poor in the outer suburbs and giving to the rich at the top end of town. The Democrats once opposed this, but now they are equally responsible for imposing this burden on the community.

I also wish to highlight the financial stress this tax imposes on the many people in my electorate with mobility problems. There are many facilities in my electorate that care for the profoundly disabled and I have been made acutely aware of their concerns with the GST. The disability pension is not a lot of money and taxis are not cheap. A 10 per cent GST increase on taxi fares will once again hit hardest those who are worst off. The government's compensation for those on the disability pension could be wiped out by the tax paid on the cost of just one taxi ride. The Democrats should recommit themselves to GST-free health care and incorporate the needs of the many disabled persons who rely on taxis to get around. The commitment made by the Democrats of no GST on public transport was based on reasonable and compassionate social policy. It now seems that this baby, like `keeping the bastards honest', has been thrown out with the bathwater.

talk.start.para: âLying about eight kilometres off Townsville is a delightful island called Magnetic Island. It has about 25 kilometres of roads, and most of it is national park. It is a jewel in the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park in North Queensland, but it is a jewel that has remained largely undeveloped. In 1983 there was a suggestion in the Magnetic Island community that it was time to have a new safe harbour. We still do not have a safe harbour some 17 years or so later. It has been a terribly long, drawn-out process where everything has been frustrated at every step of the way. But I am pleased to tell this forum that, finally, the federal government last week issued an environmental clearance for Nelly Bay harbour, which is the latest step in the project to get the thing under way.

speech.para: But there are still some concerns in that the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority will have to issue the necessary permits. They are at arms length with the government, as everybody understands. Once they issue those permits they are then challengeable in the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. The concern our community has is that those who wish to frustrate the project, and those who have frustrated the project over so many years, are now going to use this final appeal process to continue to frustrate the project. Here we have on Magnetic Island more than 95 per cent of the residents wanting this safe harbour, and we get this frustration from a handful of people who, year after year, have been denying this particular magic project for Magnetic Island, denying it to the residents of the island and of Townsville. Indeed, on the mainland the demand for the safe harbour is even higher: it runs at about 97 per cent.

So my message to that particular handful of 20 or so people is: `It is time to stand aside. It is time to get out of the way. It is time to recognise the will of the people. It is time to understand that we do need a safe harbour on Magnetic Island.' I would appeal to them not to continue to frustrate the process, not to use this last technical appeal process, because it will simply further delay the project for another three months. I believe the project will now go ahead, and I am hopeful that we will see it finished by the end of this year. It has remained a blight on the beach at Magnetic Island, because it is half-built. I am very hopeful that we will see it completed by the end of the year. It will be a magic new amenity for the island, and one that the island will certainly welcome.

talk.start.para: âOrder! In accordance with standing order 275A, the time for members' statements has concluded.

debateinfo.title: CRIMINAL CODE AMENDMENT (BRIBERY OF FOREIGN PUBLIC OFFICIALS) BILL 1999

talk.start.para: âI move:

speech.para: That the bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of the bill is to amend the Criminal Code Act 1995 to provide for new offences prohibiting the bribery of foreign officials within and outside Australia by Australians or companies incorporated in Australia. The offences are designed to implement the OECD Convention on Combating Bribery of Foreign Officials in International Business Transactions, which is a very significant response by the international community to the problem of transnational corruption.
The provisions of the proposed bill would enable Australia to ratify the convention.
The bill now before the House was passed by the Senate on 13 May 1999 with several amendments which were moved by the opposition and accepted by the government and others in the Senate.
I am very pleased that the bill was passed by the Senate with the support of all groupings in the Senate.

The message that is sent to the international community about our attitude to corruption is very important in a world where trade between different countries is increasingly influencing domestic policy.
The government certainly looks forward to being able to report to the OECD that Australia has passed the implementing legislation with the support of all groupings in our parliament.

The bill is very much one of the consequences of globalisation. We live in a time of unparalleled social and cultural interactions which demand that we have an international perspective in relation to our ethical and value systems as well as the conduct of business. I believe the bill and subsequent ratification of the convention will convey a message to the world and the Australian community that the parliament takes the problem of bribery seriously. There are those who believe official corruption is part of the way of life in some countries. However, it is almost always illegal and I doubt that it really reflects the true community values of the country concerned. However, where laws are not enforced for any reason, corruption will thrive.

While an organised international response has taken some time to materialise, the OECD Convention on Combating Bribery of Foreign Public Officials in International Business Transactions is a very significant initiative. OECD countries account for approximately 80 per cent of global GDP. The OECD includes the world's three largest trading nationsâthe United States, Germany and Japanâand includes all major European countries, South Korea, Canada, Mexico, New Zealand and Australia.

In December 1996 the United Nations General Assembly adopted a Declaration Against Corruption and Bribery in International Business Transactions. Indeed, the United Nations Economic and Social Council Commission on Crime Prevention and Criminal Justice continues to monitor progress on implementation of the declaration. The effort to combat international corruption is not limited to the OECD. Indeed, five countries that are not members of the OECDâArgentina, Brazil, Chile, Bulgaria and the Slovak Republicâhave signed the convention. So there is scope for many more countries to join the international effort to stamp out corruption.

It is important that Australia should support the OECD's initiative to combat the bribery of foreign public officials and take a principled stand against corruption. While I am sure we would all agree it will not completely solve the problem of corruption, implementation of the convention will reduce it and provide a strong statement about Australia's values and our confidence in the soundness of those values.

There is good business sense, as much as morality, in introducing this legislation. Bribery distorts attempts at international competitive bidding, bribes themselves are non-productive and are therefore paid from profits and bribes distort trade in that contracts are not based on merit and can lead to production of poor quality goods and services. In the aid context, bribery can lead to a very poor selection of projects, and this can in turn lead to diversion of resources away from areas of greatest need.

Australia considers this to be a serious international issue which is best tackled by multilateral action, and Australia considers it important that it be in a position to be part of that multilateral effort. The bill therefore follows the requirements of the OECD convention on these matters and, as such, keeps our standards in line with those proposed for other highly industrialised countries.

The great majority of the other OECD countries either have passed the necessary legislation or are in the process of doing so. Indeed the convention was able to come into force on 15 February 1999 because sufficient countries have passed the implementing legislation and ratified the convention. These include Germany, Japan, the USA, Korea and Canada.

As honourable members may be aware, an earlier version of the bill and the convention was examined in detail by the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties whose report was tabled on 2 July 1998. The government is very appreciative of the contribution that the committee's report has made to this issue and believes that the bill introduced is consistent with the report's recommendations.

I particularly thank the now retired chairman of the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties, Mr Bill Taylor, the former member for Groom, and other members for giving consideration of the convention priority and for their comprehensive public consultations. I also thank Senator Helen Coonan for her important work as chair of the OECD bribery subcommittee.

I believe that the government's establishment of a process for careful examination of and consultation on treaties prior to their signature is working well and ensures there is a full and wide appreciation of what is involved in the obligations before Australia is bound by them. The consideration of this particular convention is an example of how well that process works.

The bill proposes that the Criminal Code Act 1995 be amended by inserting part of a new chapter 4 into the Criminal Code which prohibits the bribing of a foreign public official. The main provision is clause 70.2. Subclause 70.2(1) prohibits providing or offering a benefit which is not legitimately due to another person with the intention of influencing a foreign public official in the exercise of his or her duties.

For it to be an offence, the benefit must also be provided or offered in order to obtain or retain business or obtain or retain a business advantage that is not legitimately due to the recipient or intended recipient. The maximum penalty is 10 years imprisonment, which is consistent with the penalty recommended for the same type of offence in the Model Criminal Code.

Subclauses 70.2(2) and 70.2(3) make it clear that something is not legitimately due just because the benefit or business advantage may be customary or because of its value or official tolerance of corruption. Clause 70.3 provides for a defence. A person cannot be guilty of the offence if the activity is lawful in the country of the foreign public official. I would doubt whether corrupt activities would be lawful in many countries; however, it follows that there should be a defence in those circumstances.

Clause 70.4 provides for another defence. It provides that a person is not guilty if the person's conduct was engaged in for the sole or dominant purpose of expediting or securing a routine government action of a minor nature and the value of the benefit was of a minor nature. The bill concerns large scale bribes which warrant special offences which reach beyond the usual jurisdictional reach of governments. Small payments are something left for local officials to stamp out, and it is not appropriate or practical for foreign governments to be concerning themselves with expensive international prosecutions. This approach reflects what is provided for in the convention and is similar to legislation in the United States and Canada.

Clause 70.4 also requires those wishing to rely on the defence to produce a contemporaneous record of the payment to establish their bona fides. I agree with the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties that there should be strict recording requirements, and the bill requires compliance with these before the defence can be utilised.

Clause 70.5 deals with the extraterritorial reach of the proposed bill. Consistent with the recommendations of the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties, the bill has been adjusted to reflect the overwhelming majority view of submissions that jurisdiction should be based not only on there being some territorial connection to Australia but on whether the accused is an Australian citizen or a body corporate incorporated by, or under, an Australian law.

The bill was amended in the Senate to also cover conduct outside Australia by residents of Australia who are not citizens of Australia because there was concern that some people who are long-term residents of Australia could not be prosecuted. I expect that the same practice will be adopted in relation to residency jurisdiction as has been adopted in relation to the similar residency jurisdiction provision in the child sex tourism legislationânamely, that proceedings will be commenced only where the person has been resident in Australia for at least two years.

It is the government's view that persons who are residents of Australia but not citizens of Australia at the time of the conduct should primarily be the responsibility of their home jurisdiction where the conduct is outside Australia. Accordingly, where the home jurisdiction has its own legislation in place, it would be the preference of the Australian government that proceedings be commenced against the person by their home jurisdiction.

Clause 70.6 is a savings clause in relation to other relevant laws, including state and territory laws. In some circumstances there will be an overlap with state and territory secret commissions offences. The government would not want to disturb any prosecution which is initiated under state or territory legislation. I expect in the vast majority of cases the prosecutions will be initiated under the proposed legislation because it has a higher penalty.

I believe this bill will make a significant contribution to Australia's ability to influence the conduct of international business transactions to ensure that decisions are made on the basis of the merits of the product or service and not on the basis of extraneous matters which have no place in development of trading and business relationships. In any case, the bill is also morally right and should be enacted on that basis alone. I commend the bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum.

talk.start.para: âThe Australian Labor Party strongly supports the Criminal Code Amendment (Bribery of Foreign Public Officials) Bill 1999 . Corruption has been a scourge on many countries throughout the world. Research carried out by the International Monetary Fund has shown that corruption gives bureaucrats an incentive to increase needless red tape, that it saps the confidence of investors and that countries in which corruption flourishes are those frequently which invest least in education and have fallen behind economically.

speech.para: Before I speak further on this bill, I want to acknowledge the cooperation that has happened in relation to the development of this legislation. The Attorney-General has, quite properly, recognised the work of the Joint Committee on Treaties, but I would also like to acknowledge the work of his own advisers, particularly Geoff McDonald in the Attorney-General's Department and the team that have worked with him. They met and briefed the opposition through this process, and those discussions were cooperative and fruitful. I should acknowledge Senator Vanstone's office and her staff, who were equally cooperative in relation to this issue.

On our side, I make note particularly of the contribution of Andrew Leigh in the office of Senator Peter Cook. He has been one of the key agitators, if I can put it that way, for the opposition, pressing the government on some key amendments which the government has ultimately accepted. This has been an exercise which has brought out the best in the parliamentary process and the executive government. Of course, that is frequently the way in which legislation emerges. Public attention naturally focuses on those occasions when we lock horns but, in instances such as this, it is very pleasing to be able to acknowledge the cooperation that has been extended to the benefit of the legislation that has emerged.

In the Senate, we made mention of the fact that bribery has come under the microscope as never before. Corruption has played a part in the dismissal of governments from Zaire to Brazil, in the Philippines and in Indonesia and there have been serious allegations of bribery and corruption even in the United Kingdom. From those experiences and others, the OECD convention on bribery was born, and thus this bill.

The explanatory memorandum refers to assessments of costs and benefits and trade impacts. It notes that there is a view, which has been quite properly rejected, that Australia will be disadvantaged by the adoption of this legislation. The fact is that I think Australia has been disadvantaged in international trade and commerce by the prevalence of corruption. Sometimes we do have amongst our business establishment people who are crooks, and few would deny it. They come before the courts too infrequently but, nonetheless, we could all repeat lists of those of great prominence serving time behind bars, some of whom have been at the heights of the Australian business establishment and have not been unprepared to stoop to low conduct to achieve their ends.

On the whole however, Australian business operating overseas tends to act within a more ethical framework than is the case with many other nations trading internationally. Australians tend to resent the request for financial inducements or bribery. They operate in a framework which is scrutinised by the ASC. They operate in a framework where we seek to encourage transparency in the corporate law, and it is not quite so easy to disguise illicit payments for corrupt objectives. When they do business in countries where corruption has become endemic, Australians often find themselves less able to close business deals simply because there is an implicit or explicit expectation on those with whom business is to be done that there will be a quid pro quo in a monetary or some other form going to that official before a contract can be let.

As I say, that is not completely unknown even in our own country. The newspapers have recently been highlighting the alleged exploits of someone in Sydney who goes under the sobriquet of Mr Ten Per Cent and his alleged association with a former police officer. So we should not pretend that we are coming into this debate all naive and innocent and all that do trade for and on behalf of Australian companies overseas have been entirely untouched by corruption. But that is all the more reason to have this legislation. That is a reason to say that we will not condone practices of this nature and that we think that international norms should be built to try to restrict the corrosive effect of bribery and corruption that occurs.

In mentioning those who should take some credit in relation to this legislation, I note the work of Transparency International. They have carried the public debate on this issue for a very long time and their work should be acknowledged. The opposition will also claim some credit for some specifics of this legislation, and we should. We proposed a number of amendments.

The first amendment which the government accepted was one to clause 70.2 to insert words relating to the value of the business advantage. We did that because we felt that there was a risk that a court in interpreting the legislation might take the legislation to mean that, by omission, the value of the business advantage was a relevant factor in deciding whether the business advantage was legitimately due. That was not the intention of the explanatory memorandum, and the amendment fixed that matter.

The second amendment was to address what was essentially a minor oversight in the drafting. The bill is intended to cover large payments to foreign officials to secure their cooperation; it is not intended to cover minor matters which might more appropriately be dealt with by the local jurisdiction. It accepts that, in some parts of the world, whether it is right or wrong, there is a practice of small transfers of money to facilitate the speedy issue of licencesâdrivers licences and minor permits of that nature. We might not like it but, if that is the way business is done, we have accepted that that is a matter for those local jurisdictions.

But the legislation, as proposed, referred to the payment being of a minor nature, so it left unaddressed the possibility of making a series of minor payments to secure a very large benefit. The amendments that have been now introduced into the legislation make it plain that minor payments are only possible as an exception to the general rule if they are also designed to secure minor benefits. So you cannot backdoor the legislation by washing through a series of minor payments with the aim of securing large benefits to the individual or corporation that is making the payments.

Finally, we have prevailed upon the government to accept that the legislation should apply not only to Australian citizens and corporations which have an Australian domicile but also to Australian residents. The Attorney has, quite properly, referred to the child sex legislation, which is the precedent upon which this proposal was modelled.

The reason we put this forward was that it seemed to be hypothetically possible at least that, for example, of two individuals in almost the same situation, living side by side in the same street in a Sydney suburb, one being an Australian citizen and one not but perhaps having been a resident here for 20 years and doing business overseas, the Australian citizen would be the subject of these laws and subject to quite strong criminal penalties, fines and imprisonment but his next-door neighbour could undertake that activity with impunity. That seemed a very odd and unconscionable outcome and not consistent with applying the same legal framework to all those who have Australia as their place of residence.

The Attorney quite properly points out that there is a discretion, as there is in the child sex legislation. Consent to a prosecution of a resident, as opposed to an Australian citizen, will require the Attorney's written consent, and the Attorney has indicated his preference that, where there is a concurrent jurisdiction from that person's country of citizenship, it might best be pursued in that jurisdiction. That may be so, but of course not all persons who are resident in Australia without Australian citizenship come from countries which will have adopted the OECD treaty and, of those that have adopted the OECD treaty, not all will have proposed similar legislative provisions. This gap needs to be closed. Furthermore, where a person has been a long-term resident of Australia and has, in a sense, treated this country as their country of domicile, where they have long connections and are part of our community, there seems to be no reason whatsoever in my view that we should not expect of them the same ethical and commercial standards as we expect of every other Australian citizen.

These changes were made in the Senate after negotiation with the government's advisers, Senator Vanstone and her office. I think the legislation has been improved as a result. It leaves us in a position where we are very pleased to be able to join with the Attorney. This allows Australia to feel confident that we have joined an international process which will be important in changing the way in which business is done by international companies operating in other jurisdictions. Transparency International, particularly Peter Willis and Peter Rooke, will be pleased with this outcome.

Of course all great hopes have to be tempered by realism. Prosecutions under this act will not be frequent. Offences will be hard to identify and hard to prosecute. If it is hard to identify and prosecute corporate misbehaviour in Australia, it will be more so when it is the subject of investigation by Australian citizens or residents in other jurisdictions where the legal framework may not be conducive to all the requirements that we may need to establish a case beyond reasonable doubt. We should not pretend that this will be an act which, by its overnight passage, produces simple and quick solutions and a reduction of bribery and corruption, but it does send a very strong message. It also needs to be matched with pressure from the Australian government at the international level to ensure that all those countries which have endorsed the OECD treaty pass similar legislation, because this needs to be a comprehensive network.

If you do not have a level playing field, then unfortunately it gives advantage to those who are willing to make the bribe, willing to make the payment, willing to corrupt and willing to keep in place corrupt systems in states where without that pressure and the willingness of the rich outsiders to come in and make those payments corruption would be lessened. If you do not have a level playing field, those who are immune from measures of this nature will be trading on an unfair plane. To the extent that any Australian company would lose business as a result of that, I am certain they would feel legitimately aggrieved. So there is a continuing international task for the Australian government to ensure that all those countries which have adopted the OECD charter do pass similar legislation and then move to ensure that there is an appropriate framework for enforcement.

That said, I should conclude and congratulate the Attorney, the Minister for Justice and Customs and all those who served on the joint committees and worked together towards facilitating this legislation. I think it reflects well on the parliament.

talk.start.para: âThe Criminal Code Amendment (Bribery of Foreign Public Officials) Bill 1999 is a good bill and, as the member for Denison rightly said, it does reflect extremely well on the parliament and the processes. The locking of horns that is always the focus of the media is certainly not the case in this. I would also like to congratulate the Attorney-General and, in particular, the Minister for Justice and Customs on her processes in bringing this bill towards its complete assent and passing into law. I do so from a position as a non-lawyer, as a member of the Joint Standing Committee on Treatiesâone of the pioneer members of that committeeâwhich was I think one of the very real and telling initiatives of the Howard government.

speech.para: This bill is a landmark in another wayâthat is, it is the first time a piece of draft legislation was referred to the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties for discussion, for inquiry, for public debate, for input from all of those involved, including Transparency International, and for the process of finetuning that produced the final document we have before us today. So in that regard, all of those involvedâthe Attorney-General and the justice minister in particularâshould be commended by the public of Australia for opening this bill up to discussion. In particular, as people get paranoid day in and day out about Australia's international linkages through treaties, the work of the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties on flushing out views and concerns about matters such as this legislation plays a vital role, I think, in the ongoing education of the broad populace as well as the specific section of our community who are affected by matters such as corruption and bribery in this case.

Australian business does pay a penalty for not being active participants in bribing public officials offshore. There are some very well-founded and well-documented examples of corrupt practices by bigger players in the world economy. The US Foreign Corrupt Practices Act 1977 grew out of some of the more famous ones that took place, I think it was in Japan, as a result of US companies attempting to influence officials there to gain access to market possibilities. These sorts of scandals are scandals that fortunately Australian companies have not been involved in that we know of.

The question of what a bribe was was an important thing to establish as we were involved in the inquiry. We were looking at whether a bribe really could come down to a basic simple thing like a gratuity or a tip. I guess in its purest form it probably does in one sense. As the member for Denison said, the idea of saying to a public official, `I want that particular thing off the ship fast and out of the container fast. Here is a bottle of scotch or here is $20 to make it happen,' is probably commercial reality, but in a purist sense I think that in itself is a bribe. But if we were going to, as a means of that definition of a bribe, try to transact proceedings against people, we would have the entire AFP and the legal system in the country tied up forever, I suspect.

The idea of somebody wanting to get their passport visa stamped quickly was also brought up in the terms of this inquiry. We discovered on a number of occasions that Australian companies have had to pay a little premium to an official in another country in order to get priority treatment on a visa. In itself I think that is probably arguably a bribe or just simply a payment for priority treatment. We have talked about those matters in our discussions in the treaties committee. We decided that `bribe' would mean the following:

. . . the offer, promise, or giving of any undue pecuniary or other advantage, whether directly or through intermediaries, to a foreign public official, for that official or for third party, in order that the official act or refrain from acting in relation to the performance of official duties, in order to obtain or retain business or other improper advantage in the conduct of international business.
I hope everyone understands that completely!

talk.start.para: âNot bad considering you're not a lawyer. You have already got the mumbo jumbo.

âHave I got the mumbo jumbo worked out? Well, I will apply in due course for a legal degree, following in the footsteps of the great Jim Killen perhaps. I think it is important to note that for many years in this country, and until quite recently, bribery in the form of gratuities and tips and so forth were in fact tax deductible until what was originally the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1998, which became Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1999, gained assent on 31 March. Until then, it was possible for payments of bribes to become tax deductible expenses in this country. These are all interesting matters that were brought out through the inquiry process of the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties. So the minister has done the right thing by submitting this for full inquiry to produce the 16th report tabled in July last year for further public discussion before the matter was then introduced in the Senate and now finally in the House of Representatives.

speech.para: I would like to particularly single out the work of Senator Helen Coonan, who is a lawyer. She and the member for Lyons assisted greatly the committee's direct deliberations in this matter. The member for Lyons, Senator Coonan and I became the three people who were involved in the subcommittee appointed by the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties.

With regard to the need for this convention, as I said, I think Australian businesses have probably paid an increasing penalty as companies from other nations have embarked upon potentially corrupt activities, both active and passive forms, ranging from the actual involvement in a direct payment to somebody in order to bring about a certain result or turning a blind eye to certain activities. We found important evidence that the World Bank estimates that bribes emanating from industrialised to developing countries amount to about $US80 billion per yearâ$US80 billion worth of distortion in the marketplace. The total net flow of direct investment and trade and development assistance to developing nations is about $US180 billion a year. In other words, there is a large component of bribe money, if you like, that is impacting on the direct development of underdeveloped nations in this world.

The member for Denison, as well as the Attorney-General, highlighted a number of matters. The distortion to the development of those nations is a matter that concerned the treaties committee greatly. A nation where, if you are related to the ruling entity, you are having a better lifestyle than the average citizen is an anathema to all Australians. The idea of some sort of universal franchise of involvement in our community is something we attempt to uphold, and I think we live and breathe as a nation, perhaps more than most people realise, because most people are treated on an equal footing. Everyone has a right to vote. Everyone has an equal opportunity to participate, although some perhaps need more assistance to have that equality of opportunity to participate. Nevertheless, there is none of the distortion we see in a lot of developing countries where family relationships or mateships can impact upon just how well you are travelling in the overall scheme of things. Bribery plays a role in enhancing and entrenching, if you like, those sorts of activities. For a lot of good social reasons, not just pure economic reasons, the attack on bribery which the OECD has embarked upon and which this government and, I would say, all parties, all members and senators in this place, are now party to is important. This bill is important for a lot of human reasons as well as just dollars and cents reasons.

It is also important to note that there is a real linkage in a contemporary sense between what we are trying to do with this bill and what has happened in Asia in recent years. One of the other issues that came out of the inquiry we held was that Brian Hurlock from the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry said that he regarded corruption in all its forms as a cancer in the global system of trade investment, requiring decisive and effective action to eradicate it completely. He noted that in fact there is a linkage between the current economic problems in Australia's region and endemic corruption, low level results of which he saw first-hand in refugee camps in Thailand in the 1980s and 1990s. So there is a fairly straightforward allegation that corruption in the form of bribery has in fact led to a lot of the lack of transparency and a lot of the poor systems that are at the heart of the Asian currency crisis. Again, I think for a lot of reasons this bill is very important.

The concept of making bribery a criminal offence is seen as an important first step in addressing the overall incidence of international bribery. The reason why it is rightly with the OECDâand a lot of people say that the OECD is the rich club of the worldâis exactly that.
