The US Federal Aviation Administration also wrote to the department on 21 January 1998, saying that it was working closely with Evergreen to prevent further incidents and would continue to monitor the situationâ1996, 1997, 1998; we get to 1999 and finally we have some action.

Last Friday at the Sydney Airport Community Forum, the following resolution was carried with the support of every single community representative. The only abstention, once again, was from the airlines, who see their role on the community forum as opposing the community. The resolution I moved read as follows:

Sydney Airport Community Forum (SACF) expresses alarm at the repeated incidents of fuel venting over the community in the vicinity of Sydney airport. We note that in spite of government commitments by Minister John Sharp to question No. 1557 on 24 June 1997, no regulations have been introduced. SACF demands the government introduce regulations which would include substantial fines and provision to ban repeat offenders such as Evergreen Airlines from Sydney airport during the next parliamentary sitting week beginning 31 May 1999.

What did we see? We heard a report from the department to the SACF meetings that these regulations were being prepared. More than two years after Minister Sharp, in response to a question on noticeâit is in Hansard âsaid that they were going to do something to stop this occurring. I was told on Friday that, `Something is happening, so can you just withdraw your resolution perhaps and it will all be okay?' The community found that unacceptable, because the community notes that this government has to be dragged kicking and screaming into action.

talk.start.para: âOn anything.

âOn anything, as my colleague the member for Lilley said. They prevaricate, they delay and they defer on action. What a disgrace it is that today we are debating the Damage by Aircraft Bill 1999 , which goes to the heart of this very issue, when at the SACF meeting last Friday the government said, through its department, that regulations were coming inâthat they were subject to approval that day. There is no coincidence. Something happens every time there is a SACF meeting. On the same day that the community has a spotlight on the government, we get action; and we get action because the Australian Labor Party members and community members on that forum pursue it in the public arena. It is not due to anything else.

speech.para: Commitments from government ministers appeared in Hansard, but nothing happened. What we got was a report from the department which said, `The regulations which are being gazetted today'âthe air navigation fuel spillage regulationsâ`would make it an offence to release fuel except in an emergency or with approval from air traffic control, or CASA. The regulations also empower the secretary with the right of inspection the right to ground an aircraft suspected of releasing fuel.' We got that. We asked to see the regulations and we were told we could not. We are only the community forum! We could not get them.

You would think we could get them this week, given that this bill is on. I spoke to the minister's office two days ago, and I also raised the question of what these regulations are with the Chair of the Sydney Airport Community Forum. But guess what! The regulations are being gazetted after this bill goes through the House. We cannot get a copy of the regulations so there can be no parliamentary scrutiny of them during this debate. They are going to be tabled after question time today. That is typical of this government.

In the pages of the Sydney Morning Herald on Saturday, the government proudly proclaimed, `The federal government last night approved the world's first laws allowing airlines to be grounded and fined if caught dumping fuel on residential areas.' It is an interesting contradiction. How do you ground an airline after it has dumped fuel? What do you do? While it is dumping fuel, do you radio them and say, `Hey, can you come back?' so they can dump fuel on the way back in as well? It is an interesting concept.

I welcome the fact that fines are being introduced. The figure we were given last Friday by a departmental representative was $13,000, but we do not know that because we do not have access to the regulations. $13,000âhow pathetic! We need an economic imperative that makes the cost of failing to maintain aircraft properly more than the cost of doing the right thing. We need serious penalties; $13,000 is not a serious penalty. Last Friday, the Sydney Airport Community Forum successfully carried a resolution calling for fines of up to $500,000 if planes breached the curfew at Sydney airport. What has been occurring is that a decision is made, `Oh, well. It's going to cost us a few grand. How much are we making out of this flight? We will just land. We do not care that it is midnight, 2 a.m. or 3 a.m. We will just do it because the economic benefit is there for us.'

The same principle should apply to this issue. It should be said to a repeat offender like Evergreen Airlines, `If you continue to engage in this practice of flying out of Sydney airport over the most densely populated area in Australia with planes which vent fuel all over residents for 20 kilometres after take-off, we will say that you are not welcome.' There is nothing wrong with that. As we know, Sydney airport has already told airlines like Virgin Airlines that they are not welcome. It has reached the cap. Airlines such as Emirates have moved their operations to Melbourne because you cannot get in and out of Sydney airport because of the way that that airport is managed.

There is nothing wrong whatsoever with having provisions in these regulations to say, `If you are a repeat offender you are not welcome.' If you are a bad driver, you get taken off the road. If you are a bad airline operator, why shouldn't you be taken out of the skies? This government has not provided any real disincentive. The regulations should have been tabled and should have been scrutinised by this parliament in this debate. I find it astonishing, and totally consistent with why there is such concern about the operation of Sydney airport. As with the information with regard to the expansion of the airport, with regard to the development of the precision radar monitoring system and with regard to the actual figures for the operation of the long-term operating plan at Sydney airport, there is one thing that is consistent, that is, the community has to drag the information out of this government and this government fails to provide proper community consultation.

The time is coming when the Sydney Airport Community Forum will get sick and tired of carrying resolutions unanimously that are then ignored by the government. The government has stacked SACF with its representativesâthere are five Labor representatives out of 20 on the committee, in spite of the fact that Labor represents the areas around Kingsford-Smith. But Labor has the quality representatives because it has not lost a vote yet. The people who live around Sydney airport know that this government has failed them, and it is failing them again through its failure to take real concerted action on the issue of air safety and on the issue of the wellbeing of residents who live around Sydney airport.

talk.start.para: âI rise to support the Damage by Aircraft Bill 1999 because it is of great importance to the residents of Lilley, in particular those who live around what is becoming an extremely busy airportâan airport which will have the same problems in 20 years time that the member for Grayndler was talking about if we do not get a change to the secretive approach of the operator and of the federal government.

speech.para: The only way these airports can expand is if they live in harmony with and work with their communities. The secretive approach in relation to the problems of the Brisbane airport master planâwithholding of flight paths, the venting of fuel and on-ground noiseâcontinues in Brisbane, as it has in Sydney over the years. It will produce all of those problems in Brisbane if a much more mature relationship does not develop between the communities affected, the airport operators and the federal government.

It is very good to see this bill, the purpose of which is to improve compensation for members of the public who suffer personal injury or property damage as third parties on the ground involved in air accident. It is just a pity we cannot have stronger regulation of what happens when operators and airport authorities breach their own guidelines in the operation of aircraft onto and off the airport. I will talk about that in a moment.

Aeroplanes fly all over the electorate of Lilley all day and most of the night. They fly over the suburbs of Chermside, Wavell Heights, Kedron, Gordon Park, Wooloowin, Clayfield, Ascot, Albion, Hamilton, Hendra, Shorncliffe, Deagon, Banyo, Boondall, Virginia, Nudgee Beach, Northgate and Nundah. In the last three years, there has been a deterioration in noise management procedures surrounding the airport, to which the BACL, the minister and this government have been completely indifferent.

Aircraft are deviating needlessly and causing unnecessary noise. Too many aircraft are not adhering to the correct ascent and descent profiles. In short, they are flying too low, and when they fly too low they disturb communities and also increase risk. We ought to have much more effective policing of the proper ascent and descent profiles in the electorate.

None of the residents in these suburbs doubt the importance of Brisbane airport to the economic future of our local community and to south-east Queensland in general. But now they are being told that they have to accept a new runway, when they cannot even get the operation of the current runway in proper context. They cannot get best practice at the existing runway, and the government want to expand it with a new runway which is going to double the capacity of the airport. All of this has been done without any comprehensive economic, social, environmental or public health impact statement. The federal government has approved a new runway 2.1 kilometres west of the existing runway without a comprehensive analysis of what effect it will have on the local community.

How can residents believe the BACL and the federal government when they say that the new runway will not impact upon them, when they have not implemented on the old runway the best practice that they claim they are going to implement on the new runway? This proposed parallel runway has the potential to cause serious problems in the northern suburbs. Air traffic will increase over suburbs like Aspley, Chermside, Kedron, Gordon Park, Wooloowin, Hamilton and Hendra. The location of the new runway will be close to Shorncliffe, Deagon, Banyo, Nudgee Beach, Northgate, Nundah and Hamilton. All of these suburbs will have significantly more noise if the new runway goes ahead, and it has been approved under the master plan by the federal government. In that master planâa document of some 240 pagesâonly three pages specifically examine the options. The whole document was rigged so that only one conclusion could be reachedâthat a new parallel runway be located 2.1 kilometres west of the existing runway.

The transport minister has now locked into that option, so concerned residents are constantly contacting my office regarding this proposed runway. I believe we do need to have that comprehensive economic, social, environmental and public health study. We need to have it and we need to have the flight paths, but they are being withheld as well. One reason why we will have to have a Senate inquiry into the master plan process is that locals have been left in the dark.

The problem we have at the moment is that the BACL and the federal government are continually refusing to supply flight paths. They are deliberately keeping residents in the dark. What is more disturbing is that in the master plan the new parallel proposed runway is located 2.1 kilometres west of the existing runwayâvirtually on top of a whole number of suburbs that existed in this area before the existing runway was built. These are not new suburbs; these are not homes that have been built since the airport was expanded. They have been there for 50 years. They are proposing to build a runway 2.1 kilometres west of the existing runway, virtually on top of these suburbs.

Many people come to me and they say, `Wayne, if this new parallel runway has to go ahead, why does it have to be 2.1 kilometres west of the existing runway? Why can't it be one kilometre? Why can't it be 1.2? Why can't it be 1.5?' But, as is the case with the master plan, we can get no answers from the BACL or the federal government. If this dastardly proposal must go ahead, the new runway could be located closer to the existing runway, thereby alleviating the effects on local suburbs such as Banyo, Northgate, Nundah and Deagon. But we cannot get an answer. We cannot get any analysis. We cannot get any commonsense. And if we do not get any commonsense and this proposal goes ahead, we will have the situation that we had in Sydney when their parallel runway went aheadâwe will have the whole community in uproar about this proposal. So wouldn't it be better in the interim if we just had some consultation, if we could just develop some faith, if we could just get rid of the secrecy and if we could just get a dialogue going? We need the jobs and we need the economic expansion, but we do not need a divisive debate which will kill the potential economics of this airport and bring with it the divisiveness of Sydney and all of the things that came with it, such as curfews and the like. If this goes ahead, make no mistake, that is the future that we will be looking at in Brisbane.

Wouldn't it be good if the BACL and the federal government also paid some attention to air quality in the area? We are now dealing with a bill that compensates people for damage. Why don't we talk about compensating people for damage that comes from the venting of fuel over their suburbs? As the member for Grayndler said before, we have been constantly pressuring the federal government to do something about this. We are now told there are regulations, but those regulations could not even be given to us before this debate today. We had an example of a Qantas jet that vented fuel over Brisbane not too long ago. I have been told that it was not immediately over the airport area, but how many jets have been doing it that we do not know about?

In the new environmental planâin the master planâthere has been a study of the impact on the immediate environment of the airport site, but no studies of the air quality in the suburbs immediately surrounding the airport have taken place in Brisbane. Why don't the BACL and the federal government get together and work with those local communities so we can have some analysis of air quality and so residents can be assured that their quality of life is not being adversely affected by the sorts of incidents that have been occurring in Sydney?

I call on the BACL and the federal government to do something substantial about measuring air quality in the suburbs immediately surrounding Brisbane airport. That would be something that would naturally complement the sorts of initiatives that are in this bill today. The health and welfare of all of those residents in those suburbs surrounding this community must be paramount because, if this airport is to expand, there has to be a broad community consensus behind it. It cannot expand, and it will not be able to operate effectively, if that consensus is fractured.

That consensus is being fractured by the failure of the government to provide the flight paths for the parallel runway, the failure to put in place sufficient environmental standards and measurement, and the fuel venting incidents that we have seen in Sydney. There is a need for a tighter regulatory approach. As the member for Grayndler said, at the end of the day, the way we can regulate this is going to be economic. In Sydney and Brisbane we have to have tougher fines for aircraft operators who do not adhere to the regulations, tougher fines for aircraft operators that vent fuel and tougher fines for aircraft operators that rev their engines on the ground in the middle of the night and wake up most of the people surrounding those suburbs.

We need tougher regulation so that we can get an effective transport industry that lives in harmony with those people who are, in the first instance, most adversely affected by the economic growth of an airport such as Brisbane. We need that. It is commonsense. Why can't we get some commonsense out of the federal government? Why can't we get some genuine consultation? Why can't we get some genuine regulation?

I call on the federal government and the BACL to change their practice of the last couple of years and do something decent to deliver genuine consultation and collaboration between the airport community and the airport in the long-term interests of the north Brisbane suburbs and the generation of jobs and wealth in our community.
Debate interrupted.

talk.start.para: âOrder! It being approximately 12.30 p.m., I propose the question:

interjection.para: That the Main Committee do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: âOn 9 February 1998 Christopher Corrigan gave evidence in the Industrial Relations Commission matter 30432 of 1998. He was asked:

speech.para: In taking the steps that you did to approach Mr Wells, what financial obligation if any did that involve you or Lang Corporation, or Patricks in in terms of the recruitment of the personnel?

His answer was: `None.' When asked if Patrick, Lang Corp or he personally accepted any financial obligation with respect to the recruitment of the Dubai workers, his answer again was: `No.' Industrial Relations Commission Vice-President Ian Ross relied on these answers in granting section 127 orders under the Workplace Relations Act, which revolved around the question of whether or not allegations of deceitful conduct had been proved.

There is overwhelming evidence that these statements by Mr Corrigan were not true, that he knew they were not true and that therefore he committed perjury. An affidavit by Mr Michael Wells dated 6 May 1998 indicated as such and has a number of documents attached to it which indicate that what Mr Corrigan said was not true. There is a document entitled `Confirmation of an agreement to act'âan agreement between CTMS and Patrickâdated 23 October 1997, in which CTMS agrees to recruit on behalf of Patrick and, in return, gets a $30,000 retainer from Patrick, a $4,000 per week management fee plus a 10 per cent placement fee; a line of credit to CTMS from Patrick is agreed and Patrick is also obliged to pay for the overseas travel of Mr Wells and Mr Kilfoyle.

Second, there are bank records of Fynwest Pty Ltdâanother company involved in the exerciseâwhich show $140,000 paid to Fynwest by Patrick. Third, there is a deed of immunity between Lang Leasing Pty Ltd and Fynwest Pty Ltd of 1 December 1997. The bank records were dated 9 January 1998. Fourth, there is an invoice dated 15 December 1997 to Patrick from International Port Services Training marked `Attention: C Corrigan' for $392,000. Fifth, there is a letter from Chris Corrigan dated 17 February 1998 to Fynwest, effectively acknowledging a financial obligation to Fynwest. Finally, there is a letter from Corrigan to the CTMS lawyers dated 8 May 1998, claiming that the 23 October agreement had been breached and referring to `the loan provided by Patrick to Fynwest Pty Ltd'.

On 5 October 1998, the Registrar of the Industrial Relations Commission referred the perjury question to the DPP. According to the answer given by the Attorney-General on 5 May 1999 to a question on notice from me:
The Director's office advised the Registrar on 2 November that on the material provided the Director was unable to determine whether an offence had been committed.
The Attorney-General also advised me that the matter had not been referred to the Australian Federal Police.

This is an absolutely scandalous situation. Overwhelming documentary evidence indicating that Mr Corrigan has committed perjury has been referred to the DPP and he has not even seen fit to refer the matter to the AFP for further investigation. Mr Corrigan has not been interviewed. Mr Wells, who has alleged in an affidavit that Mr Corrigan perjured himself, has not been interviewed. Mr Kilfoyle has not been interviewed. I call on the Attorney-General and the Minister for Justice and Customs to explain this extraordinary situation. Why are the serious accusations of perjury against Mr Corrigan not even being investigated? If the government is unable to answer this question, public confidence in the independence and competence of the DPP's office will be seriously undermined.

If Mr Corrigan is aggrieved that I have raised this matter in parliament, I urge him to exercise his right to make a formal reply in parliament. Indeed, I challenge him to respond to these accusations. Perhaps he might explain to us how a person who enters into an agreement to finance the recruitment of the Dubai mercenaries, who transfers money in accordance with that agreement and who seeks to enforce that agreement can swear on oath that the recruitment of these workers did not involve him and his company in any financial obligation. Perhaps the Attorney-General can explain to us how it is that this behaviour does not attract the investigative activity of the Australian Federal Police and has led the Director of Public Prosecutions to the conclusion that there is no evidence of an offence. This is a scandalous situation, and the government should be called to account for it.

talk.start.para: âOnce again I feel I must rise in this debate to express my concerns regarding the ever pervasive violence portrayed in the media and in film, video games and the music industry within our society which our children and young people are subjected to. I would like to make reference to two articles which appeared in yesterday's edition of the Australian : one by leading Australian film-maker George Miller and one by Jane Mills, head of screen studies at the Australian Film, Television and Radio School.

speech.para: Mr Miller's article calls for prudence in regard to the issue of violence in the media. The article refers to tragedies like Port Arthur and Dunblane, saying that our worldâ`a world which has little or no moral complexity'âknows only `that guns are the answer to almost any problem'. Of course, for some within our society, this notion is very true, even for those of us who realise that guns and violence are not the answer. Sadly, there are those who are victims of those who do not realise this. Today, more than ever, it is obvious that the media impinge on our lifestyle to a greater degree than ever before. As Mr Miller states, the media influence `what we wear, the way we talk, the way we move, the way we play as children'. Therefore, how can we dismiss the influence of the media as a non-issue in relation to influencing our behaviour on a mass scale?

On the other hand, Ms Mills claims that there is no hard evidence to prove that today's society needs to be prudent and have media censorship. Rather, Ms Mills turns the blame on the current government, saying that the government:
. . . fans the flames of moral panic and blames the screen for what it is reluctant to address.

For goodness sake! I cannot believe that Ms Mills is not aware of the role of the Office of Film and Literature Classification which refuses classification of, on average, one or two films a week. Why? Not everybody is able to distinguish between reality and fantasy.

If Ms Mills wants hard evidence to prove that today's society needs to have prudence with regard to entertainment, then I encourage her to enter a school playground and talk to the teachers, and indeed the students, about the influence that certain aspects of the media have on our children. What is becoming evident is that stories written by our primary school children are about murder, violence and rape. What happened to the happy stories about the family, friendships, life dreams or even the family pet?

I know that some teachers at several schools in my electorate during the height of the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles frenzy actually asked parents to come to the school during recess and lunchtime just to help supervise the children at play who were acting out, mimicking, copyingâwhichever terminology you wish to useâthe violent, aggressive fights and the play scenarios of their heroes. I dare say that pizza vendors experienced a huge increase in demand during that timeâand I should know. As a mother of three very active young boys, I banned the cartoon Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtlesâyes, it was censoredâin my home because I could clearly see the influence it was having on their so-called play scenarios. Every night at teatime, it was, `Why can't we have pizzas like the Ninja Turtles, mum?' I will not mention the merchandising aspect of the Ninja Turtle craze.

Once again I make the point that if the censors are failing in their responsibility to keep our screens clear of violence, such as cartoons aimed at children, then it is up to us as parents to be ever vigilant as to what our children are exposed to and what we think is appropriate for entertainment. Too many times I have seen cartoons and drama series on television which have portrayed unnecessary and inappropriate levels of violence, and this material is being designed for children to view. A cartoon I watched many years ago with my children in the lounge room was a sadistic, violent portrayal of the Three Bears. Daddy Bear was continually verbally abusing Baby Bear, calling him stupid, dumb, useless, hopeless and no good, while at the same time beating him around the head and body with a four-by-four, laughing all the time. It made me feel sick to the stomach to watch, so I turned it off so my children did not have to see it. On complaining to the television station, the response was, `You don't have to watch it.' That is okay for my children, but what about young children who are not supervised and do not have the commonsense to turn it off? What child would?

As I have said many times before, my biggest concern about the whole censorship debate is the level of violence in the entertainment industry and the effect that violent role models can have on our young people. If Ms Mills is so convinced that we do not need censorship because media and films do not affect our behaviour, I would like her to explore the reasons why the advertising industry spends billions of dollars each year in order to change, modify and influence our behaviour on a daily basis, to encourage us to behave the way they want us to and to have us spend our consumer dollar on their products. Where is the prudence in that, Ms Mills? (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: Champion of Champions Small Business Awards

talk.start.para: âTwo weeks ago, four small businesses based in the Fairfield City area in the heart of my electorate were recognised by the inaugural Champion of Champions Small Business Awards for Sydney and the Central Coast as being the leaders in their highly competitive and demanding fields. Today, it is my great pleasure to read their names into Hansard and, in so doing, recognise not only their achievements but also the extremely high standard at which they conduct their business.

speech.para: The four businesses that received awards at the ceremony are: the Fairfield Fish Markets, Chic Skin Care Clinic, Bossley Park General Store & Deli, and Horsley Building Supplies. All four establishments are assets to the wider Fairfield City community. I offer the owners, their families and their staff my warm congratulations on their effortsâand what efforts they are!

Like all successful small businesses they have not reached this elite level without much hard work and sacrifice. Long hours have been put in; overwhelming challenges and disappointments have had to be overcome. The fact that they have made it through and reached this level reflects highly upon them all.

Each of the four businesses had recently been recognised as leaders in our community by winning their category at the Fairfield City Small Business Awards. The fact that they have now gone on to be acknowledged as leaders in their fields throughout Sydney and the Central Coast is certainly something which they can be proud of and which the whole of the City of Fairfield should wear as a badge of pride. The awards they have received are recognition of the outstanding levels of customer service, dedication, commitment and innovation that you can find in each one of their establishments.

The Champion of Champions Small Business Awards is the biggest and most prestigious small business awards program to have been launched in Australia. At the award ceremony in mid-May over 2,000 people were in attendance to congratulate the winners in 26 different categories. The judges, which included representatives from the Small Business Development Service, Tourism New South Wales, the Restaurant and Catering Association, LBW & Partners Chartered Accountants, Australian Flowers magazine and Good Fruit & Vegetables magazine, focused on the unique features belonging to each small business, such as the way they stayed ahead of their competitors, how the business was marketed, levels of customer service, benefits offered to customers, training of staff, and so on.

Obviously, Fairfield City's winners were considered to be head and shoulders above the rest of their competitors in all of these respects. No other area in all of metropolitan Sydney achieved such a level of success in these awards. Out of the 26 different categories from which the judges chose winners, most areas contained one or sometimes two award recipients. For Fairfield City to have four winners represented was simply outstanding.

I say to George Costi, his family and staff of the Fairfield Fish Markets; to Lois Yaghoubpour, her family and staff of the Chic Skin Care Clinic; to Joe De Abrea, his family and staff of Bossley Park General Store & Deli; and to Renzo Valleri, his brother, his family and staff of Horsley Building Supplies: you have really shown that Fairfield City is one of the small business centres of New South Wales.

These four establishments are examples of how we do business in Fairfield City. We are a centre of business excellence and high standards. Anyone who wants to see what it is really like to receive incomparable levels of service and the best products should do their shopping or even conduct their businesses within Fairfield City.

Once again, I congratulate those four excellent small businesses on their outstanding achievements. I wish them many, many more years of awards and successes and, more importantly, I am so proud to say that they are within my electorate of Prospect. Too often we pick up a newspaper and all we read is bad news. I am saying it is about time we started to read the good news and acknowledge the hard work, the determination and the spirit in which they started their businesses off, the confidence that they had in the area and the way they have grown as our areas have grown. I congratulate them again and we are so very proud of them all.

talk.start.para: âIn an adjournment speech in parliament last night Anna Burke, the member for Chisholm, made claims about the recently opened migrant information centre that ranged from the blatantly uninformed to the blatantly untrue. It is of concern to me, Mr Deputy Speaker, because this migrant information centre which the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs opened last week is one in which the community can take great pride for its establishment and for the service which it will deliver to the entire eastern suburbs of Melbourne. It is also a migrant information centre which has been much anticipated by the community and one which I, along with a number of other community minded individuals, pursued relentlessly so that it would be established in Melbourne's east. There was quite a lot of establishment time spent on this migrant information centre to make sure that it truly represented the community and helped to resolve the issues which new settlers have in the eastern suburbs of Melbourne.

speech.para: There were a number of claims that the member for Chisholm made which I would like to put straight. Her first claim, which I am very surprised at, is that the migrant information centre, which is in Mitcham, is in the City of Maroondah. Only poor knowledge of the local area, sloppy research or inability to read a map would allow Ms Burke to conclude that Mitcham was anywhere but in the City of Whitehorse. This is absurd because the City of Whitehorse is a city which both the member for Chisholm and I share, and such sloppiness, at least, I put down to her inability to research.

The other claim is that the migrant information centre was `initially earmarked for Box Hill'. The migrant information centre was never earmarked for Box Hill or anywhere else. The migrant information centre covers the municipalities of Booroondara, Manningham, Whitehorse, Monash, Maroondah, Knox and Yarra Ranges, a considerable geographic region within Melbourne's east. Box Hill was one of many locations looked into as possible sites, and at the end of the day Box Hill was not considered an ideal location for the service because it was not considered to be in the heart of that region and also because of financial constraints associated with available rental space in Box Hill. But it was given a fair hearing from all the board members.

Furthermore, the Labor government refused to give Box Hill an MIC for 13 years. It took this coalition to set up the MIC in the eastern suburbs of Melbourne, and one has to ask: why after 13 years? Undoubtedly, they refused to set one up because they did not believe that the immigrants in Melbourne's east were worthy of their support, unlike the migrant information centres that were established in other parts of Melbourne, such as in the west, the north-west and the northern suburbs.

She goes on to say it is a `puzzling decision' that `has been shrouded in controversy'. There is no controversy. The decision to locate in Mitcham was endorsed by all board members, including those of Labor persuasion. She talks about the `contentious appointment of the member for Deakin to the board'. Everyone knows of my indisputable strong links with the migrant community, apart from the fact that I was instrumental in the establishment of the migrant information centre. My appointment was supported by all board members and follows the precedent set by the former Labor government, which had the Hon. Clyde Holding on the board of the migrant information centre in Port Melbourne. I do not think being a member of parliament detracted from Clyde's ability to be impartial when it came to board decisions, as it won't be with me.

She talks about the `disproportionately high salary of the centre's CEO'. This migrant information centre follows a new management model, one which embraces the community. The CEO's remuneration is in line with what is required to entice a professional with the skills required to do the job.

She talks about the government having `gutted the family migration stream'. Labor's actions in the Senate to disallow the parent migration reform forced over 2,200 people to join a long waiting list rather than receive expedited entry.

The member for Chisholm's comments are a slap in the face to the dedicated staff at the migrant information centre, who are working with the community for greater harmony, understanding and acceptance of our newly arrived immigrants, and I look forward to her supporting the migrant information centre rather than attacking it without any truth.

talk.start.para: âI rise again to speak about the wonderful area in which I live and which I represent, Greater Western Sydney. This region contains 1.6 million people and over 60,000 businesses with a GDP of $35 billion, which makes it one of Asia's specific premier centres for economic development, global trade and capital investment. I wish in particular to speak about some of the commercial developments in Western Sydney that will lead to future employment opportunities.

speech.para: Recently I attended the launch by Mr Bob Carr, the very successful NSW Premier, of Greater Western Sydney as the call centre location for Australian industry. This scheme is being promoted by the Greater Western Sydney Economic Development Board and is intended to use the rapidly growing call centre industry to provide training and employment opportunities for local residents. Call centres, the telephone reception and customer service departments of medium to large companies, are increasingly being relocated from head offices in the city to regional centres where operating costs are cheaper and staff are readily available.

With a growth rate of approximately 25 per cent per annum, the call centre industry is one of Australia's fastest growing industries. Two-thirds of Australian industry is concentrated in New South Wales, with the overwhelming majority in the Sydney area. When you consider that 60 per cent of all those who work in the CBD live in the Greater Western Sydney regionâwhich is an area from Homebush to the east, Camden to the south, Emu Plains to the west and Baulkham Hills to the northâthe potential pool of staff makes this area ideal for the establishment of a call centre as well as other industries.

The Greater Western Sydney Economic Development Board hopes to capitalise on the cultural, geographic and economic strength of the region and to attract hundreds of new call centre operations. The board hopes to create 35,000 jobs in western Sydney from this development over a 10-year period.

para.inline: A division having been called in the House of Representativesâ
Sitting suspended from 12.51 p.m. to 1.03 p.m.

talk.start.para: âBefore the suspension, I was talking about call centres in Greater Western Sydney. While Greater Western Sydney has the transport networks, telecommunications infrastructure and government support necessary to become a prime resource for call centres, there is a further major reason why Western Sydney will be chosen: our most important resourceâpeople. What a call centre needs most is educated, motivated and multilingual people who enjoy working flexible hours. One-third of Greater Western Sydney's 1.6 million people speak a second language. Two-thirds of this region's labour force have secondary qualifications, and a number already work in this service sector. This region is already the home of some of Australia's largest call centres, including those of AGC, MMI, St George, Colonial State Bank, Sharp, IBM, World Vision, James Hardie and Integral Energy.

speech.para: The President of the New South Wales Call Centre Management Association, Mr Charles Stephens, has backed the program to promote Greater Western Sydney as an Australian base for call centres. Mr Stephens has stated:

When you consider that 60% of all those who work in the C.B.D. live in the Greater West, the potential pool of staff in this area is just another benefit that makes it ideal for the establishment of a call centre.

Cheaper rent, more space, a pool of currently skilled and potential staff living nearby, the ability to have part-time workers and reduced staff attrition all make this region an attractive location for employers to move to.

The training of the Greater Western Sydney population in specialised call centre agency skills is also assured with the launch of a new Call Centre Traineeship Centre. The managing director of Customer Focus Group, a training company specialising in call centre and customer service traineeships, is confident that the nationally recognised program will ensure that those wanting a job in the industry will be able to develop the skills to get one. I welcome these moves to attract additional industry to Greater Western Sydney.

talk.start.para: âQueensland's tilt train, the City of Rockhampton , set an Australian railway speed record on 23 May when it reached a speed of 210 kilometres per hour just north of Bundaberg. It is interesting to note that it achieved this speed while carrying its full complement of six loaded passenger cars on an uphill grade.

speech.para: The tilt train began service last November on the Brisbane-Rockhampton run, where it normally travels at approximately 160 kilometres per hourâthe fastest narrow-gauge regular passenger service in the world. The service has proved enormously popular with the people of my electorate. It shows what can be achieved by rail transport with appropriately engineered infrastructure, state-of-the-art rolling stock and a focus on airline type passenger comfort. I would like to extend congratulations to the CEO of Queensland Rail, Mr Vince O'Rourke, whose leadership has been quite exemplary, and to his teamâin particular to Bundaberg drivers Ken Cavanagh and Greg Robinson.

The previous speed record was set in New South Wales in 1992 when an XPT reached 193 kilometres per hour. The tilt train service has reduced travelling time from Brisbane to Rockhamptonâa journey that used to take 14 hours just a decade agoâto a mere seven hours today. The trip from Bundaberg to Gladstone in my electorate, one of the fastest legs, which takes 2Â¼ hours by road, now takes only 1Â½ hours by tilt train. This is the basis for a cultural change in modes of travel.

I would also point out that, in the next quarter, a second service will commence from Bundaberg to Brisbane, taking people from Bundaberg at 5 o'clock in the morning, bringing them into Brisbane at Roma Street just after 9 a.m. and bringing them back at a similar time in the afternoon, from 5 o'clock till 9 o'clock. This will make a huge difference to people who wish to travel to Brisbane for business, doctors, shopping and a range of other matters. We should also recognise that these beautifully crafted trains with their airline type seats, television, sound, et cetera, were put together by Walkers Ltd at Maryborough; they too need to be congratulated.

When trains in Europe are running regularly at 350 kilometres per hour and freight trains at 180 kilometres per hour, it is a joke that trains on our major trunk routes are forced to travel between 10 and 65 kilometres per hour. We are an international joke when it comes to travel. But mercifully the Queensland system has now set a new standard for the whole of Australia. It may not yet be to European standards, but it is certainly a quantum leap for this country.

I would recommend that the government take up a number of the recommendations of the report Tracking Australia. One of our recommendations in that report was that there be $750 million in the short term to fix the worst deficiencies in the national track. If you do not get the track right, there is no way that the trains, whether they be passenger or freight, can move at an acceptable speed. Once again, I congratulate Queensland Rail, in particular Mr Vince O'Rourke and his team, for an outstanding service and hope that the tilt train will go on to set further records and enhance passenger travel within this country.

talk.start.para: âI rise to extend my sincere condolences and care to a constituent of the Dunkley electorate, Bev Knopfmacher. Mrs Knopfmacher was given the devastating news that her world renowned husband, mathematician Mr Knopfmacher, while in Austria delivering lectures to university students, had passed away. Since that devastating time Mrs Knopfmacher has been fighting a battle against the insurance company that provided travel insurance to Mr Knopfmacher. GCU Insurance has been less than helpful at this difficult time for Mrs Knopfmacher.

speech.para: Since learning of her husband's death, Mrs Knopfmacher has sought to have her husband's body returned to Australia and buried in a manner befitting her faith. Her faith also prescribes that the burial be carried out without delay. Having advised the travel insurance company of her husband's situation, she has run into repeated frustrationâand I share her view that it can only be described as unbelievably cruel.

First of all, she has been asked to prove that there was not some pre-existing medical condition, a subject that is ordinarily canvassed at the time the insurance is taken out. Those of us who have taken out travel insurance would be aware that we have to complete a declaration relating to our health condition. So, even during this difficult and devastating time for Mrs Knopfmacher, she has had to fish through medical reports simply to validate the statements that accompanied the medical health insurance statement when travel insurance was taken out.

Having done that, GCU are insisting now that an autopsy be carried out on the body of Mrs Knopfmacher's husband in Austria. As if it is not hard enough for her to cope with her devastating loss, she is now faced with having to deal with another jurisdiction in another country, having to juggle with a 12-hour time differenceâand all she wants is her husband's body brought home. This is not a matter of a discretionary operation that has occurred as a result of something happening while Mr Knopfmacher was on travel; this is an emergency of the gravest kind. He deserves to be returned to this country without further delay.

Mrs Knopfmacher does not need her grief and devastation compounded by the heartless and cruel actions of GCU Insurance. I call on GCU Insurance to do the right thing: to honour the insurance policy that has been taken out in good faith and to recognise the family's desire and, I think, justified need in having the body of their husband and father returned to this country for burial.

I would also like to acknowledge the assistance being provided through Minister Downer's office with consular support and also the interest and concern shown by Peta Tomlinson, the chief journalist at the Mornington Peninsular Leader newspaper who has joined me. Together we are hoping to get a satisfactory outcome for Mrs Knopfmacher. She is so devastated by what has gone on, she is so appalled by the conduct of GCU Insurance that she, personally, is now considering paying for the entire costs of returning her husband's body to this country just so that she can have the burial in a manner that befits and is prescribed by her faith.

It is outrageous that someone in her situation should be subjected to this sort of bureaucratic obfuscation. I call on GCU Insurance to do the right thing to assist one of its clients and to look after the needs of Mrs Knopfmacher at this very difficult and traumatic time for her.

talk.start.para: âOrder! The time allowed for the debate has expired. For the future reference of the Main Committee, I indicate the procedure that was undertaken today when the adjournment debate was interrupted by a division in the chamber. A reading of standing order 274A in part indicates:

interjection.para: Provided further that, after the debate on the questionâThat the committee do now adjournâhas continued for 30 minutes or until 1.30 p.m., whichever first occurs, the Chair shall interrupt the debate . . .

On this occasion we have interpreted `has continued for 30 minutes' as indicating that the adjournment debate should go for a total of 30 minutes, and that was the procedure that was undertaken. The committee stands adjourned until a date and time to be fixed by the Deputy Speaker.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 11 May 1999:

question.para: (1) Further to the answer to question No. 479 (Hansard , 31 March 1999, page 4100), in which he acknowledged that some employers willingly employ illegal workers, (a) which departments participate in the inter-agency Cash Economy Working Group, (b) what are its terms of reference, (c) how many times has it met since it was established and (d) what recommendations has it made to ensure that employers and employees meet their fair share of the tax burden.

(2) Has the maximum penalty of $10,000 which may be imposed on an employer who is convicted of having knowingly employed unlawful non-citizens been reviewed; if so, (a) when was the last occasion it was reviewed and (b) is there a formula to review the penalty.

(3) Since his appointment as Minister, has his Department recommended the prosecution of employers for knowingly employing illegal labour; if so, did the Director of Public Prosecutions refuse to act on the recommendations; if so, on what grounds.

(4) Is it a fact that since 1988 only one employer has been convicted of being knowingly concerned in visitors working without permission but locations of illegal workers and overstayers increased to 12 679 in 1997-98; if so, (a) does this indicate a weakness in the Employer Awareness Campaign and (b) are his Department and associated enforcement bodies failing to rigorously pursue the possible prosecution of employers for disregarding the law.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr Ruddock
talker.role: Immigration and Multicultural Affairs; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) (a) The regular participants of the Inter Agency Cash Economy Working Group are the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (DIMA), Centrelink, and the Australian Taxation Office (ATO). Other government agencies, such as the Department of Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business and the Office of the Director of Public Prosecutions, attend as required.
(b) In March 1997, the ATO, Centrelink, and DIMA formed an Inter Agency Cash Economy Working Group to examine opportunities for joint activities.
The activities of the Inter Agency Cash Economy Working Group include:
. investigating the possibility of undertaking joint prosecutions for taxation and social security offences;
. outposting Centrelink officers to ATO sites;
. improving cooperation and information exchange;
. identifying potential joint activities.
(c) Since its establishment in March 1997, the Inter Agency Cash Economy Working Group has met twelve times.

(d) The Inter Agency Cash Economy Working Group is an informal working group. It is not a body tasked with recommending to Ministers. Agencies may take ideas and information from the working group and incorporate these into their portfolio responsibilities.

The Inter Agency Cash Economy Working Group has played an active and critical role in fostering joint activities, extending co-operation and improving the exchange of information between the three agencies. It continues to develop new approaches and monitors the progress of those, which have been put in place.

(2) (a) The amount of the maximum penalty of $10,000, which may be imposed on an employer who is convicted of having knowingly employed unlawful non-citizens, has not been reviewed since it became part of migration legislation in September 1994.
(b) There is no formula to review that penalty.
(3) Since my appointment as Minister, there have been no briefs to the Director of Public Prosecutions in respect of employers who knowingly employ illegal workers.
Prosecution of employers who knowingly employ people with no work rights is possible under section 5 of the Crimes Act. Prosecutions, however, have rarely occurred because of:
- reluctant supporting witnesses
- insufficient evidence to prove "knowingly" or "intent" by employers
- the chain of evidence required to meet prosecution standards.
(4) I refer the honourable member to my answer of 31 March 1999 on the number of employers who have been convicted of being knowingly concerned with visitors working without permission.

(a) The Department has been conducting the Employer Awareness Campaign (EAC) since 1992. The EAC encourages employers to check the work rights of prospective employees and provides them with information on how to do so.

The EAC has been a valuable tool used by my Department to help those many responsible employers in Australia who remain committed to ensuring that they employ only Australians and workers with right to work.

(b) I have previously indicated my Department's efforts at identifying and acting where people are working without authority. I am concerned, however, that under current law there is no obligation on employers to check the work rights of employees and that it is difficult to establish sufficiently well, for prosecution purposes, that employers may knowingly have recruited people without work rights.

The Review of Illegal Workers I have commissioned will consider, among other things, the adequacy of provisions available to discourage employers from recruiting people without the right to work. The review will also examine the adequacy of information available to employers.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Family and Community Services, upon notice, on 11 May 1999:

question.para: Has the Commonwealth provided funding to Equal Vocational Employment Network (EVEN) Inc. and its associated organisation, Zenith Employment and Training; if so, (a) what sum did it provide in (i) 1996-97, (ii) 1997-98 and (iii) 1998-99, (b) on what programs, activities or products did EVEN and Zenith spend the funds and (c) was portion of the funds used to finance a proposed contract with the Eden Fishermen's Recreation Club under which EVEN/Zenith would assume responsibility for managing the club; if so, (i) what sums and (ii) on what items.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Family and Community Services has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (b) In accordance with their service agreement, Equal Vocational Employment Network (EVEN) Inc. and its associated organisation Zenith Employment and Training, provided outcomes for people with a disability through employment preparation, job search, employment placement and post placement support.
The Agency also provided specialist services to people with a disability from a Non English Speaking Background, and to school leavers.
(c) (i) and (ii) Nil.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 12 May 1999:

question.para: (1) How many former crew members of HMAS Melbourne have initiated legal proceedings against the Commonwealth in connection with the HMAS Voyager disaster.
(2) How many of claims (a) have been resolved in favour of the applicant, (b) have been resolved in favour of the Commonwealth and (c) are still unresolved.
(3) What total sum in damages has been awarded against the Commonwealth.

talker.name: Scott, Bruce, MP
Mr Bruce Scott
talker.role: Veterans' Affairs; Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (2) (a) and (b) 1 case was resolved in favour of the plaintiff by the court, the other 17 resolved to date have been settled by agreement out of court.
(c) 95 remain unresolved.
(3) One, McLean at $696,450.00 plus costs. The remaining cases were settled out of court, and accordingly are not awards of "damages". Settlements have totalled $4,231,450.00.
